text:
first off, we didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> have reservations but they were able to fit us in before we went to go see santana....(disclaimer: yes, i am under the age of 30 :))

started with the duck fat fries trio, <mark>Shellfish Platter</mark>, kobe beef carpaccio... so far, everything was great!  some people mentioned that their fries were not crispy but ours were perfect...these fries were much better than the ones that i had at citrus at social....

i had the kurobuta pork along with the butter poached <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark>...r had the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>. the pork was awesome but the <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> was lacking.  honestly, how can you mess up on lobster?

sides that have accompanied our meal were the truffled mac & cheese, the black <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> peas with chorizo and rapini, stone ground grits, the potato puree trio, and the jalapeno creamed corn.  i wil have to say that the sides were perfection.  serious comfort food yo~

we ended our meal with beignets along with our expressos....the beignets were a nice finish to our meal.  also, they provided us caramel popcorn as complements of the chef and it was a great little perk to take with us at the concert.  the greatest thing about our meal was the fact that they were able to get us out of the restaurant so that we didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> miss the concert.  

honestly, they would have received 5 stars if it wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> for the bad lobster.... again, who really messes up on lobster?

stripsteak is the best steakhouse i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> been to in a long time and a complete opposite to the morton<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> type steakhouses. we had various lobster, <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> and other seafood apps (all good) and i had the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> cooked rare. a great "value" given that it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> only $18 over the $54 regular filet. my only regret is not getting the japanese kobe! one thing that i didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> think was so special (but not enough to take away a star) was when we were served duck fries "compliments of the chef". listen, they<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> just fucking fries, ok?

as you will see from my reviews i have eaten at high end steak places in ny, philadelphia and dc.....this is definitely in the top 5 of all of them.   

we went here with a group and ate on a thursday night, we had no problem getting a table for 4 at 8pm with reservations.   

i had the <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> bacon appetizer which was honestly the lowlight of my meal but still very good.   my wife had a beet salad which looked nice and a friend of mine split onion rings with the table.   the free fries were also amazing and we loved the different sauces.

next came the main courses.   my wife ordered a filet done perfectly.   my friends gf had the halibut which was also excellent.   i had the regular <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> and the <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> options as did my friend.   let me just say this steak was seasoned and cooked perfectly.   the <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> legs that were the side were amazing.   they were split and all of the good parts were left.   a great addition! 

we got the mashed potato sides  as well as a mushroom that was part of a forrest fire.   

i think that this is a great steakhouse and a great place to eat.   i would highly recommend this place in lv.

people have always told me the food in vegas was awesome. i dated a girl who lived in vegas for a while and never experienced anything like i did when i went to stripsteak, at the mandalay bay. 

quality cuts of meat, waitstaff who knew what they were talking about, and as it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> been mentioned: duck fat fries!!! these delicious fries came prepared (i.e. seasoned) three different ways with three different sauces. i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> drooling just thinking about those sweet, sweet fries... ((mmmmghghgh))

my friend and i shared a porterhouse with some <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark>... it was nearly a religious experience. the steak was so tender, i could<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> sworn it simply fell apart in my mouth. i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> never had such an amazing steak. don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> get me wrong, it hasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ruined me for other places, like ruth<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> chris or boa, but it cer<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> set a very high standard. it needed absolutely no further seasoning and was cooked perfectly. the <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark>, well, it was good, but then again <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> is fairly consistent from place to place. 

pricey? yeah, but well worth the throwdown. i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> glad my friend dragged me here, because she really made an excellent pick - as i ate, there was nowhere else on earth i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> have rather been.

compared to other steak houses i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> visited in las vegas, stripsteak is middle-of-the-road. if i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> going to spend a lot of money i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> rather dine at carnevino, cut, or delmonico. if i want a decent steak at a more affordable price, i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> go to twin creeks.

my wife and i arrived early -- about <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> hour before our reservation. the hostess still seated us promptly at a small circular two-top, but in the back of the lounge, in between the bar and the main dining area. it was very comfy -- her on a long bench with big cushions, me in an oversized chair -- but not ideal for eating a meal because of how low the chairs are in relation to the table. add to that the deafening sound of all the lounge chatter and music and it was difficult to have a conversation.

the food wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> bad at all. as a matter of fact, some of it was great. but, i think there<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> better value to be had elsewhere.

to start you off, they bring out a complimentary trio of fries (old bay flavored, garlic herb, and truffle oil). all were some of the best fries i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> had, with the garlic herb being my favorite. they were perfectly crispy, light, and addictive. we had to force each other to stop eating them and save room for the rest of our food.

//appetizers//
sweet onion soup ($17) - morels, parmesan crouton. excellent depth in flavors, earthy and delicious mushrooms.

main <mark><mark>Grilled Maine Lobster</mark> Fritters</mark> ($20) - bacon-wrapped fritters. three per order. the <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> was masked by the oiliness and saltiness of the dish. but the crispness and coolness of the lettuce wrap was a nice compliment. not worth getting again.

//entree and sides//
10 oz. filet ($56). they were nice enough to split it for us since we wanted to share. ordered it medium rare, but it came out closer to rare. tender and savory, but not nearly as good as the filet at carnevino.

two sides of <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> ($24 ea.). each order con<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> two meaty <mark>King Crab Legs</mark> with lemon. served cold, it could have benefitted from some drawn butter.

shallot potato cakes ($9) - scallion creme fraiche. three cakes. perfectly crispy, great flavor... kinda like the greatest hash browns you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ever have.

english peas ($14) - shaved fennel, pancetta. peas are peas, nothing extraordinary, but the pancetta added a good bit of savoriness and salitness.

overall, the food was pretty good, service not very attentive, the sommelier suggested a wine we weren<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> crazy about, seating was comfy but not functional, and it was too loud to carry a conversation. oh, and i forgot pricey. but we did have a $50 restaurant.com gift card that helped mitigate the damage.

3.5 stars

fantastic! the good was amazing, the drinks were delicious, the presentation was great, and the service was good! its a fancy restaurant, so expect to pay for it. i would highly recommend the steak tartar and the <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark>.

working 8 days straight at the mandalay, strip steak was our go-to place for our protien fix.  

believe it or not, french fries fried in duck fat are complimentary.  omg, talk about delicious.  they offer you 3 different types of dipping sauce but honestly, it isn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> necessary.  the fries are addicting.  you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> been warned ;)

the porterhouse is reasonably priced ($78?) and is big enough for 2 people.  there<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> no wow factor as porterhouse is usually the same at most places.  it is served with some pearl onions and baby carrots.  

chilled seafood is also a good starter.  the portion could have been bigger but the selection was quite good..  it had <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark>, <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark>, a few <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> legs, a couple oysters and a couple clams.  i could have eaten the whole thing myself, but i had to share =)

salads were decent but way overdrenched.  be sure to ask for light dressing.

it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> a nice decent steakhouse, but definitely not a destination restaurant.  do try it out if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> staying at the mandalay.

we sat at  the bar, <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> legs, to start, <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> and steak tartare, cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> and wine, everything was perfect as usual, nice job! we will be back!

another wonderful meal in vegas! we came here to celebrate my stepmom<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> birthday and everything was fantastic! our waiter was awesome, the drinks were superb, the food was top notch, and the ambiance was great! no complaints about stripsteak at all.

for cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> i highly recommend the cucumber martini and the moscow mule. both of those drinks were phenomenal. their drink menu is an ipad with a really cool interface that allows you to easily browse all their drinks.

we were served complimentary fries upon our arrival, since there were five of us, they brought two servings of them. all the fries are cooked in duck fat and seasoned differently, i know for sure one was truffle, but i don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> recall the others. the dipping sauces were great, one was truffle, one was mustard, and the other i don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> remember, but everything was delish.

i split the <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> with my stepmom, so they gave each of us a small bowl. my favorite <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> was at craftsteak, but they can move over, because my new favorite is at stripsteak. love, love, loved this bisque! 

i ordered the grilled <mark>Diver Scallops</mark>, which were delicious and reasonable. four large scallops for under $40 is a pretty good deal, especially in vegas. they are mesquite grilled and they were wonderful. 

i sampled everybody else<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> food, all of it was amazing!

halibut - also mesquite grilled, light touch of lemon. perfect.
<mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> legs - served with drawn butter and lemon, and they removed the shells for my sister in law, very nice of them!
dry aged bone-<mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> - only one person ordered steak at the steakhouse, lol, but it was one of the best <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> i have ever tasted. i would get that if i come again.
<mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> burger - awesome burger with a really good mustard flavor to it.

for sides we shared the truffled mac & cheese with peas, <mark>Potato Gratin</mark> with gouda sauce, and the creamed corn with jalapeno. all amazing. the portions appeared to be pretty small, but they were actually perfect considering all the other food we had, we ended up leaving some of the sides behind.

for dessert with ordered the beignets with the <mark>Trio of Sauces</mark>. we were given six light, airy, hot beignets with a very scotchy butterscotch sauce, a creme brulee sauce, and a chocolate pudding sauce. mmmmm, i would come back to this restaurant just to get dessert again!

dinner was $600 after tip, for five people, lots of cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark>, entrees, sides and dessert. pricey, but about what to expect when you come to a nice steakhouse in vegas. i hope to dine here again someday!

ummm....what didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> i eat here? not sure because i practically died of food coma afterwards. please don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> judge our fattiness....here we go!

5) creamed corn: i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> made this from the recipe cook, taste, eat by mm. um...it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> 10x more fantastic in person.

6) potato puree trio: my personal fav was the lobster. sour cream & onion, and horseradish were close seconds.

main entree:
8oz <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>. so good. but i definitely <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> my friend<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> 14oz bone in fillet (special of the day) 
<mark>Half <mark>Grilled Maine Lobster</mark></mark> - grilled.

4) mascarpone cheesecake: harry<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> berries, basil, pistachio streusel....could not take another bite..

i think that<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> all. i can<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> remember anymore at this point, lol.

we came here with the mgm execs and they hosted our dinner with patically everything on the menu, steaks were well aged, sides were as expected of michael mina. delicious.

must orders: appetizers <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> or tartar, <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> or bisque dont forget the <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> slidders. 

main, dry ages <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>, <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>, of course a5 japanese <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> with <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark>, <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> or just top any steak with <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> butter. why not? 

sides spicy zucchini, smoked mushrooms and <mark>Roasted Bone Marrow</mark>. 

deserts: everything..we literally had everything. 

a true perk when you work for an event company, the restaurant sites. they serve you only the best on the menu, at this place they served everything and everything is the best.

solid steakhouse (coming from a texan). i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> been here a couple of times and have thoroughly enjoyed both meals.

quick hits:
1) best old fashioned ever. if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> never had an old fashioned, this is where you become addicted. if you have had an old fashioned before, this will raise the benchmark. order the "specialty cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark>" old fashioned ($16?) ...didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> know there was a difference but the waitress brought us some ter<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> looking ones during our second round.

2) bar/waiting area waitstaff is friendly. dining room waitstaff is friendly, but extremely slow and unattentive. like, really slow and unattentive.

3) <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>: delicious, tender, chewy, can<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> stop won<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> stop.

4) 18 oz <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>: "them bones doe". jk. this is a solid choice and can be shared if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> getting a ton of other food

5) seafood platter: broken up individually amongst 3 of us: <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark>, <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark>, claw, 3 or so oysters, 1 jumbo shrimp -- think it was around $34

6) added <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> to the steak: it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark>, what do you expect?

7) <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> butter: too foie-y and not worth the upcharge

8) a5 wagyu - for $34 an ounce with a 3 ounce minimum , i was thoroughly underwhelmed. it was good, but not great. i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> stick with the other steaks listed above

9) kale salad - $17. quite literally something you could go to the grocery store and reproduce for less than 3 dollars. nothing special

10) <mark>Diver Scallops</mark>: nicely seasoned and delicious

11) complimentary fries with 3 dipping sauces: all. so. good. beware: do not fill up on these

12) alcohol/wine menu on an ipad. cool, i guess...

13) note: if you have a reservation, expect to wait for a little bit (our wait time was 30 minutes) until you get seated!

stopped in at strip steak for a quick dinner and i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> glad i did!

service was excellent - our waitress was extremely
attentive and helpful.

food was very good - pretty standard steakhouse fare in vegas. got the kale salad which was very tasty but a little bit too much dressing and the fois <mark>Crispy <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> Dumplings</mark> which were good but extremely rich - i could only eat two of the tiny dumplings.

had a filet <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> oscar style with broccolini - and it was awesome! the steak was like butter and the garlic broccolini was delicious and cooked perfectly.

prices are a little high for what the food is, and the atmosphere is a little loud and somewhat "sports bar" - but it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> vegas so any steak dinner worth eating on the strip is going to set you back a few dollars.

after camping out at the lazy river all day, i made an  last minute reservation at 6:10pm via hotel for my parents<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>. we arrived  ten minutes early, and the hostess directed us to our table 7:30 sharp. our waitress was extremely well versed on the menu and offered some excellent suggestions. the music was a clubby and electronic feel that didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> overwhelm us. i had the <mark>16 Oz Ny Strip</mark> and <mark>Alaskan King Crab</mark> legs to share with others which was excellent ! the cream of corn as a side dish is off the chain!! however, i was extremely disappointed in the dessert menu, they offered ice cream, plain cheesecake and beignets. my birthday guests were hoping for some type of cake or chocolate offerings. 
so we settle for coffee - which powered us for long night of partying for our last night of vegas.

overall, our experience at this facility was positive and everyone in my group had a good time. despite a disappointing dessert menu - i wouldn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> mind coming back to getting a bite of those delicious stakes!

a friend of mine that i consider a food and wine expert recommended this place to me.  also, it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> a michael mina restaurant and i have been to his place in san francisco and it was excellent. the ambiance is modern and open, but doesn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> seem that classy to me.  the service was average.  the <mark>Caesar Salad</mark> my date and i had were flavorless.  my steak was very fatty and expensive too.  the meat that i could eat from it was good.  the creme de brulee dessert was very good.  overall, i would never go back especially for the price.  the fries they put on the side for free on the table are tasty and the bread is different.  it comes in a skillet and is good.  the aparagus and bake potato sides were like most steak restaurants, expensive and huge, but good.

make sure that you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> in the mood to eat when you come here, because if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not, you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> still going to eat a lot anyways.

made a group trip out to vegas for the 4th of july and decided to come here for a nice dinner.  wrong place for me because i don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> eat beef, but everyone else wanted to come here so i tagged along.

we brought in a double magnum of 2007 acre cabernet sauvignon (4 bottles of wine in 1).  the service was standard, nothing too great for that caliber of restaurant, but nonetheless, we had a good time.

we ordered <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> menu pretty much.  everyone got steaks except me, i  had the chicken with truffle macaroni and cheese and onion jus.  rick moonen<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> chicken blows this one out of the water. for starters, we had the <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> cheese with tomato bisque, crab louie lettuce cups with a sriracha aioli and <mark>Caesar Salad</mark>.  all the starters were really good.  for sides, we ordered the jalapeno creamed corn, truffle mac and cheese, potato au gratin, asparagus, and some other sides.  and most everyone got the $72 kobe filet (everything is priced a la carte).

then why the reason for 3 stars?  3 for service, 4 for food and ambiance.  when we paid for the bill, our server somehow "misplaced" $100 of our bill after we left her an extra $35 on gratuity.  all in all, the problem was fixed and the general manager, mark, was very professional about the situation.

before you take my review to heart, please know that i am in the fine dining industry and i understand both the guest perception and service staff perception.
overall, our dining experience was wonderful....... food, service, price!
now on to the actual review:
5:30pm reservation time, showed up early for a little hh cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> and was promptly seated for dinner soon thereafter. our server, although very soft spoken and a little difficult to hear, was attentive and nice! he gave us the perfect amount of time to order, and the food started to flow out of the kitchen.
compliments from the chef: duck fat fries: hello?!? heaven in my mouth!
1st course: kobe beef tartare- beautiful presentation! tartare came out on a plate with the quail egg set atop with all the mix ins surrounding. our food runner gracefully mixed the tartare and placed it in a chilled glass. grilled pita bread to go with. we both decided that the pita bread and the tartare were great........ separately! the pita bread masked the steak when eated together.
2nd course (his): wedge salad: wow! crispe cups of iceberg lettuce, bacon, blue cheese dressing (which was not too "blue cheesy"), and pickled shallots.
2nd (mine): hearts of romaine, which i automatically pegged for their version of a <mark>Caesar Salad</mark>. it was and it wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>. the menu states "olive" dressing....... after my first bite, i remembered that olives are not my most favorite....... my fault!
main entree (his): rack of lamb. perfect mid-rare with the most incredible rosemary sauce drizzled over the top.
mine: grilled scallops: cooked nicely...... nothing over the top. my very last bite did have a grain of sand which sends chills down my spine, but it was just the one. i appreciate the work, talents, and dedication of the prep all the cooks/ chefs to back there do before service starts. one graine of sand won<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> kill me.
sides: <mark>Brussels Sprouts</mark> with bacon-de-lish! potato pur\u00e9e: sour cream- average, lobster- incredible, horseradish- in between.
dessert (his): beignets with 18 yr scotch butterscotch pudding- the pudding was amazing. you got all the favors of both the scotch and the butterscotch. perfect pair!
mine: mascarpone cheesecake: the best cheesecake i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ever had! huckleberry compote, shortbread crumble, and candied kumquat peel...... amazing!
all savory food came out very quickly, almost too quickly. by the time dessert came around, service drastically slowed down. as i stated at the beginning of this review, i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> in the industry, so i see both sides of it.
at the end of the day, would i go back? absolutely!!!
other reviews state that the price is to high, blah, blah,...... but you need to remember, you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not just paying for that steak on a plate..... you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> paying for the technique of food preparation, service and everything in between. so, if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> worried about how much money you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> going to spend, don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> go out to a restaurant like this because you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> leave pissed off when in all actuality everything was great until the bill was dropped. 
i left happy! :)

stripsteak is, by far, the best steak i have ever eaten in my life. i went there first to take clients out to dinner late last year. we all started with the <mark>Caesar Salad</mark>, which was very impressive. the "chef<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>" duck-fat fries that arrive at the table are such a nice treat, and awesome.

for dinner, i got the skirt steak which was cooked to perfection. for my side, i got the bacon-<mark>Creamed Spinach</mark>, which although i was close to a heart-attack, was beyond delicious. we had no room for dessert, but the waitress sent all of the ladies off with some caramel popcorn, a really nice touch.

the scene: 18 of my closest friends and me for my birthday party.  september 2015

the menu: the "holstein" pre-set dinner menu (with upgrades)

we all get it - vegas is pricey.  but instead of paying $30-$50 for what amounts to fancy dorm food at a buffet, i decided to live it up a bit for my birthday.  therefore, months of planning led to this epic dinner.

first of all, given the sheer size of my party, i knew there would be some small issues.  stripsteak does not have a private dining area, but they set up a nice table for my guests.  the ambiance was perfect for my type of outing - trendy, and cer<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> upscale without being stuffy, where you would have to worry about using the wrong fork and be without another for the rest of your night, as punishment.  i would probably give 4 stars as an individual rating for the "value" of the set-up vs. what it cost, but then there was...the food.

ahh yes, the food.  what really matters.

first of all, pretty much everything at stripsteak is served with complimentary duck fat fries.  deliciously crisp and decadent, and accompanied by 3 dipping sauces (but good enough to not require any accompaniment.)  now here<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> a little secret - still have a small ghetto streak in me where i like my fries served with my steak, so it was a little strange to have these as an appetizer, but surely a great way to start off the meal.

per their menu, my group had the choice of salad or a shrimp cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> appetizer, entree of <mark>10 Oz Prime Flat Iron</mark> steak, chicken, or salmon (i have no idea how the non-steak items tasted.)  upgrades to <mark>10 Oz Filet Mignon</mark> or <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> were available.  and given the decadence of my spending, an upgrade for sure was necessary.  (more on that below.)  additionally, sides were served "family style."  broccolini, pureed potatoes of three flavors (sour cream and chive, lobster, and i can<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> remember the other), and truffle mac and cheese.  the truffle mac and cheese was the highlight for many of my guests (the ones that didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> order steak.)

ahh yes, the steak.  peruse their menu and you will see that michael mina doesn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> drive to a corner butcher to get his cuts.  with all respect to usda grading of beef, this night required a little international flavor...in the form of...

world wide wagyu.

anyone who has done steak research knows that japanese beef is luxurious but also a curiosity.  "kobe sliders" at your local bar and grill for $12 have more in common with an aging basketball player than they do true kobe beef.  even cows that are designated "wagyu" may not be imported from japan.  so, this mini world tour consisted of three cuts of wagyu (beef derived from a line of japanese cows that are bred in other countries.)  these cuts:

<mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> - <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> is the new trendy top cut of meat.  it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> generally the best couple ounces of your <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>, made even better when it comes from a well-marbled <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>.  this cut had a perfect sear and set all my umami sensors afire.

<mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> short rib - tender, fall-apart, as if it were braised.  (i didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> check to see if it was actually braised short <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not.)  

finally, real japanese "a5" grade wagyu <mark>10 Oz Filet Mignon</mark>.  a5 is the highest grading that <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> have in japan, based on beef yield, color, and the all-important marbling score.  i wish i could have seen a photo of it before it was cooked, to visualize all the delicious marbling.  after cooking, it tasted like pure meat butter.  delicious.

after a meal like this, i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not sure if i can ever go back to eating steaks even at fancy local steakhouses.  of the three, i am declaring the <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> the winner in an ever so slight margin over the japanese a5 filet (though, likely, just because it was <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>).  the australian came in third, but was still delicious.  wagyu, you may have ruined me for life!  thank you, stripsteak, for introducing me to it and making me an addict.  

thank you also for an incredible birthday with a ridiculously good meal.

ooooooooh lord! this place is going straight to the top of my porkbelly paradise list. seriously though, i would come back just for that succulent, perfectly flavored, slightly crunchy yet still juicy and amazingly divine  p o r k   b e l l y.  honestly i can<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> talk about much else right now, because i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> drooling all over my keyboard while i dream about it. how am i going to tell all the other yelpers about the entire experience? i can<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>. too bad! you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> just have to hear me go on and on and on... and on and on and on... about the pork belly. 

okaaaaay fiiiiiine, i suppose i should help people figure out if they should dine here blah and try some steak or maybe blah eat some other dishes or wine dessert blah. i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> try to move on, i swear. here goes nothing!

food:
---------
to be honest, not much else stood out during this meal other than my soulmate (aka pb). everything else was slightly underwhelming. 

surprisingly, the complimentary **duck fat fries** were pretty bomb, and the second best thing we ate here. very light and crispy and goes well with any of the <mark>Trio of Sauces</mark>.

second up was our appetizer, none other than the incredible! super edible! pork belly--its proper name being **instant bacon** ($22). see opening paragraph for my full assessment of this dish.

since this is a steak place, we figured we<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> better order one. the **10 oz <mark>10 Oz Prime Flat Iron</mark>** ($48) did not live up to expectations and was definitely not worth the cost. even thought it was done medium, the meat was dry and lacked flavor. super disappointing.

for side dishes--often the best part of any meal--we got the **<mark>Potato Gratin</mark>** ($17) which came with gouda and the **<mark>Creamed Spinach</mark>** ($14) topped with bacon streusel. both were decent but neither really met my side dish hopes and dreams. however, they did make the steak easier to eat!

the **vanilla cheesecake** with strawberries and shantilly cream was the chef<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> special for the night. it was simply perfection. thank you to executive pastry chef monica delgadillo for helping us end the night on the right note.

---------------------------
the storefront is super impressive with full glass panels and brightly lit signs indicating your dinner destination. even the reception desk outside is lit up, so there<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> no question where you start your journey. the attire here is mixed, some in cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> dresses and others in casual/business casual attire.

from the hosts to the servers to the bussers, everyone was extremely pleasant. our server was particularly helpful, especially since he<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> the one who alerted me to.... pork belly!!!! aka instant bacon. i will be forever grateful.

date tip: you can test out someone new when you lose it over the instant bacon.

up next, the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> wagyu.  running a3 - a4 quality, these steaks are tender with a more pronounced beef flavor.  the fat is nowhere near as sweet as the a5 but still plenty good.  opt for the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> if available.  it has the deepest beef flavor and is by far the most delicious.

Australian Wagyu</mark> offered as a tomahawk is very good.  to be shared (even if the bartender tries to tell you you can eat it by yourself - <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> bigger than stomach - epic fail).  a step down in tenderness but if beefy flavor is what you want, good balance.

all steaks (except the a5) have a very good sear, cooked to temp, with a very even core.

sauces and toppings if you must; <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> butter is liquid crack.  talk about richness with the distinct livery flavor of the foie.  pairs beautifully with the bitterness from the wood burning grill.  note:  do not add this to the japanese a5 unless you want a heart attack.

sides are meant to be shared.  do not pass on the truffle mac and cheese, <mark>Baked Potato</mark> with bacon marmalade, or <mark>Roasted Bone Marrow</mark> topped with a matsutake chimichurri (the tiny bits of matsutake add an unmistakable umame finish).

service is practiced and polished.  very knowledgable.  steakhouse friendly.

the wine program remains strong though somewhat lacking in vintage depth.  many great choices.  vegas resort pricing.

raising the bar once again for the top tier steakhouses in vegas.

the plate presentation is simple: steak, a whole roasted shallot and yellow pepper and garnished with a small sprig of thyme. no fluffy presentation for the main dish. there<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> room on the plate to place your sides.  it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> a steakhouse after all.

i asked out server how the steaks are cooked and she said, "they<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> poached then grilled and basted with a wine butter." i did some research to get the de<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> of how they cook their steaks.

step 1: steaks are placed in slow-poaching chambers, which enhances flavor and tenderness. the meat heats for several hours at a low temperature. 

step 2: steaks are then grilled on a cast iron grill above mesquite wood. the wood gives every cut of steak a nice subtle smokiness.

small red velvet cake pieces, powder sugar, toasted pecans, cocoa nib ice cream lay on top of the chocolate custard. this dessert was smooth and rich like a very thick pudding. the topping provided a nice contrast.

i was so full by the end of dinner. anyhow, the steak dinner was a nice way to close out our weekend of vegas fun. cost for a party of 4 with tax was $335 (alcohol $49, steaks $213, sides $24 and dessert $24).

anyone who has done steak research knows that japanese beef is luxurious but also a curiosity.  "kobe sliders" at your local bar and grill for $12 have more in common with an aging basketball player than they do true kobe beef.  even cows that are designated "wagyu" may not be imported from japan.  so, this mini world tour consisted of three cuts of wagyu (beef derived from a line of japanese cows that are bred in other countries.)  these cuts:

<mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> short rib - tender, fall-apart, as if it were braised.  (i didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> check to see if it was actually braised short <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not.)

stripsteak, a steakhouse brought forth by the all-powerful michael mina, is rightfully located in the mandalay bay resort & casino as the perfect sin city restaurant. 

why do you ask? stripsteak is a vegetarian and kosher eater<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> hell, but to a carnivorous foodie, it is simply the garden of eden. it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> a place where giant haunches of beef are hung up to age in a wall-to-floor ceiling glass case, not unlike a display at a natural history museum chronicling the stages of decomposition, or rather, the stages to one delicious steak. 

and the food, oh, the food. as i write this, my mind is wandering back to the memories from that deeply satisfying meal. 

first, i had the trio of duck fat fries--each fry was a dream, with a shatteringly crunchy, smoky shell and a fluffy interior. my friends and i fought over the truffled fries and light garlic aioli especially, but the bbq dusted fries and the original were stellar as well.

and if that wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> enough, we also ordered their <mark>Spinach Souffl</mark>, as an attempt in incorporating some vegetables in our meal. the state-of-the-art souffle was placed on the table by the server with great care as to not deflate the impossibly high, cloud-like confection. then, he took it to a even higher level by pouring a luxurious parmesan cream sauce from a dainty saucer. just as the fairy godmother transformed cinderella into the belle of the ball, mina transformed the dowdy spinach into a classic french beauty.

but even the beauteous <mark>Spinach Souffl</mark> couldn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> hold a candle next to the rib-eye, for that steak has been through rigorous training. first, it begins its epic journey in the aging room, where<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> kept in a moisture and temperature controlled room to slowly mature for a month. the chef then trims the the sides of beef with an expertise not unlike a plastic surgeon to remove all unsightly dried bits and excess fat before portioning it into perfectly formed steaks. the next step is crucial: the steak is then poached in butter. a big no-no in the kosher community as they forbid the fraternizing of meat and diary, but in my world, a big oh yes. for the finishing touch, the rib-<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> then charred in their 1,000 degree grill for that deep smoky sear. 

the best part was that the steak came to our table au naturale. with steak this juicy and well-seasoned, there<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> no need for a-1.

it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> impossible to fall into a deep food coma coming out from a meal there, but it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> oh so worth it. a definite must-eat destination for my next vegas trip!

i asked out server how the steaks are cooked and she said, "they<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> poached then grilled and basted with a wine butter." i did some research to get the de<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> of how they cook their steaks.

step 1: steaks are placed in slow-poaching chambers, which enhances flavor and tenderness. the meat heats for several hours at a low temperature. 

step 2: steaks are then grilled on a cast iron grill above mesquite wood. the wood gives every cut of steak a nice subtle smokiness.

another trio dish we ordered. the 3 flavors were: horseradish, <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> sour cream. the puree was seasoned nicely. all of the purees were smooth, rich and creamy.

passion fruit pieces, red grape fruit, thin slices of avocado, and coconut sorbet sit atop the panna cotta. the panna cotta itselft was refreshing, light and subtle sweet. the avocado gave the dessert extra creaminess and weight. while the grapefruit and coconut sorbet gave it a tart and sweet pairing.

small red velvet cake pieces, powder sugar, toasted pecans, cocoa nib ice cream lay on top of the chocolate custard. this dessert was smooth and rich like a very thick pudding. the topping provided a nice contrast.

the following review is based on one dinner experience:

service: 5 stars

our server was very quick, attentive, and friendly.  she was all about enhancing "the experience".   she was also accommodating to all our special requests and knowledgeable.  what i thought was cool about this place was that when i asked for another side of the mustard for the fries, they didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> just bring me a small cup, but decent sized bowl.

starters-

main-

Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> restroom and that others could remain unisex.

summary
overall, it was a very good meal for the price.  9/10.  i would definitely go back again.

food
i had the pre-fixe meal for $65.  helpful hint: i had to ask for the pre-fixe menu.  they do not just give it to you.  also, they said that the <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> on the pre-fixe menu is the same size as the regular order.
before the regular appetizers and entr\u00e9es, they brought out 3 cups of french fries, each cooked differently (including one in duck fat) and each with a different dipping sauce (ketchup, aioli, and truffle oil).  i thought the fries cooked in the duck fat with the truffle oil sauce were great (10/10).  you just can<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> go wrong with truffles.
i had the crab cake as an appetizer.  it was a lump crab cake, which is my favorite, as it had chunks of crab instead of shredded pieces.  it was very good (9/10).   it reminded me of legal sea foods on the east coast.
i had the <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> was my main dish and they did slightly overcook it.  it was supposed to be med-rare, but it came out closer to medium.  the meat was tender and had a dry rub on it.  it was a very good steak (similar to ruth<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> chris, capital grill), but not in the upper echelon (maestros, sw steakhouse, del friscos). 8/10.
i had the root beer float with 2 chocolate cookies for desert.  the cookies were soft and warm and tasted good.  the root beer float had 2 small scoops of vanilla ice cream, but it also had a scoop of a frozen root beer.  it was a nice way to finish off a meal, but it was nothing spectacular. 6/10

service
the waitress was full of energy and was friendly.  she checked up on us throughout the meal and made sure we were doing ok.  i would love to have her again.  10/10

ambiance
i could call the restaurant modern and trendy, not old and stuffy.  it has glass partitions between booths so it has an open air concept.  they have different furniture in different areas so it looks like they tried to create "sections" without having walls.  you can see the meat handing and aging in the center of the restaurant.  9/10.

the best all-around steakhouse i have ever had the pleasure of eating at.  

it is hip and stylish with premium appointments all around you.  fine dining meals and de<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> oriented serving but at the same time very casual.  come as you are to stripsteak.

i have eaten here a dozen or more times over a period of about 5 years.  in my opinion, steak does not get better than this.

this last visit, i had the pleasure of meeting chef gerald chin.  he talked with me for almost a <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> about the kitchen and showed me a couple cool tricks too.  i was very impressed...he is a super nice guy.

you can get some really massive <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>, but for me the high end stuff is way out of my price range.  the most expensive steak i have had here is the kobe a5, which i was not impressed with anyway.

the signature steak is the kobe <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>, now market price because mina probably depleted the whole worlds supply. it was about $80 before, but you can expect to pay between 80 and 100 now.  this is butter poached and then finished on a wood fire.  truly amazing.  they have immersion heaters that keep clarified butter at poaching temperature.  when an order comes up they just take one out of the bath and grill the outside...so the level of doneness is determined by the immersion heater, not the grill.  this guarantees you will always get a steak cooked perfectly to your desired temperature.

my favorite appetizer was the <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> sliders...but sadly they are no more.  there are tons of pics of them to see if you want.  

i got to taste a new dish (it just rolled out the night i went there) which was a trio of <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark>.  there was a seared piece on top of gingerbread, a financier of foie (small french cake), and a miso-poached torchon.  all were topped with a piece of quince and some sprinkled hazelnuts.  such an amazing dish.

if you are in vegas, i highly recommend you make your dinner reservations here.

this place was absolutely tops. one of the best steaks i have ever had and one of the best all around meals i have ever had.

for drinks i got the sampler of scotches for $30 or something. so worth it. the meal total was over $800 or something, but there were no complaints. just a bunch of very stuffed and happy customers.

one of my favorite places to eat in vegas... if you could stomach the price tag.

world wide wagyu.

anyone who has done steak research knows that japanese beef is luxurious but also a curiosity.  "kobe sliders" at your local bar and grill for $12 have more in common with an aging basketball player than they do true kobe beef.  even cows that are designated "wagyu" may not be imported from japan.  so, this mini world tour consisted of three cuts of wagyu (beef derived from a line of japanese cows that are bred in other countries.)  these cuts:

<mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> short rib - tender, fall-apart, as if it were braised.  (i didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> check to see if it was actually braised short <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not.)  

finally, real japanese "a5" grade wagyu <mark>10 Oz Filet Mignon</mark>.  a5 is the highest grading that <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> have in japan, based on beef yield, color, and the all-important marbling score.  i wish i could have seen a photo of it before it was cooked, to visualize all the delicious marbling.  after cooking, it tasted like pure meat butter.  delicious.

the food... expensive, but worth it. the fries they bring out, with the sauces, awesome. we all had the 10 oz filet... cut like butter... awesome. the sides, potatoes, <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> n cheese... spectacular. the caramel dessert, the port wine, and the overall wine selection, all on point. 

cannot say enough about this restaurant. even our booth, between all the glass, wood, and open space floor plan, was sexy and cool and fun. just a great place. take your wife, your clients, whoever to stripsteak. and hope brian m is working....

our stay at the mandalay bay resort this past week led us to tryout this wonderful restaurant.   the food is absolutely fabulous!  they start you off with perhaps the best. french fries that we<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ever tasted!  the seafood and steaks are outstanding! you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> got to try the tuna, salmon & waygu....truly awesome!!! service is a1 as well!

cow done right.

yet another 2.5 years from my previous review.  yet another dozen visits in that time.  stripsteak continues to evolve and prove its dominance as one of vegas<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> steakhouses.

this is a steakhouse so starting with the steaks.  japanese a5 is back.  although the brand is not specified, one slice into the heavily marbled beef (if ordered simply seared and raw on the inside) showcases its classic, deeply marbled, gentle beefy flavor, and melting sweet fat.  as good as it gets and at $35/oz, well worth it.  tip:  do not order more than 6oz.  the richness will fill you up very fast.

up next, the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> wagyu.  running a3 - a4 quality, these steaks are tender with a more pronounced beef flavor.  the fat is nowhere near as sweet as the a5 but still plenty good.  opt for the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> if available.  it has the deepest beef flavor and is by far the most delicious.

an <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> offered as a tomahawk is very good.  to be shared (even if the bartender tries to tell you you can eat it by yourself - <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> bigger than stomach - epic fail).  a step down in tenderness but if beefy flavor is what you want, good balance.

finally the angus beef.  if you love <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> beefy flavors, it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ahrd to pass on the udsa <mark>10 Oz Prime Flat Iron</mark>.  a true butchers cut.  packs mineral, beefy flavors.  good chew and nicely integrated fat.

all steaks (except the a5) have a very good sear, cooked to temp, with a very even core.

sauces and toppings if you must; <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> butter is liquid crack.  talk about richness with the distinct livery flavor of the foie.  pairs beautifully with the bitterness from the wood burning grill.  note:  do not add this to the japanese a5 unless you want a heart attack.

sides are meant to be shared.  do not pass on the truffle mac and cheese, <mark>Baked Potato</mark> with bacon marmalade, or <mark>Roasted Bone Marrow</mark> topped with a matsutake chimichurri (the tiny bits of matsutake add an unmistakable umame finish).

bouncing back to starters, three true standouts, the mina classic foie with roasted pineapple, brioche, coconut milk and macadamia nuts, the braised ox<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> french onion soup, and the steakhouse staple, classic <mark><mark>8 Oz <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> Tartare</mark>.  all taste as good as they read.

service is practiced and polished.  very knowledgable.  steakhouse friendly.

the wine program remains strong though somewhat lacking in vintage depth.  many great choices.  vegas resort pricing.

raising the bar once again for the top tier steakhouses in vegas.

they should call this place chickenstrip because the <mark>Mary<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> Free Range Roasted Chicken</mark> is absolutely epic. i decided to skip the steak, figured i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> prob had better. chicken was sooo tender, fell off the bone in huge delicious chunks. i had with a pinot from central cali and it was a great pair. i started with the french onion soup, it was almost as good.  you get to the bottom of the soup and then realize that you forgot about the braised beef that has been marinating and waiting for you at the bottom. awesome.
only real complaint was that the waiter wouldn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> stop trying to up-charge, but maybe that<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> just a sign of a good professional waiter. i can forgive that.
great dinner nice surprise

located: mandalay bay
happy hour:  every day from 4 pm to 5:30 pm! 

yummy!!!!

ok this place has it all.. well almost. the husband and i decided to treat ourselves to a nice little dinner. we were super happy to know that this place also has happy hour so we showed up for that. 

* i ordered their white sangria. unfortunately i should have maybe ordered some wine. the sangria was not tasty because it was soooo sweet. not my type of drink but maybe others would like it. i would say skip the sangria and stick to wine or beer.
* we ordered the smoked hummus for appetizers. that hummus was good! you had the nice smokey taste in it without being overwhelming. the pita bread was tasty too and warm. 

as for dinner:
* we were hoping to get their prefixed dinner but unfortunately we found out after seating down for dinner that they no longer had it. we were started with their well known complimentary duck fat fries that are served with different dipping sauces. i love fries so no matter what, i knew they would be good!
* we also ordered the yellow <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> sashimi. super duper, fresh, served with a bit of cucumber slices and some crispy rice and a little hint of chili. best yellow <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ever had! i would have been one happy girl with two more orders of this all for myself (and i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not one to choose fish over beef). $22
 * for main dish we ordered 8oz of mishima reserved wagyu <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>. this is the first time i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ever had <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> it for sure set the standards high. the meat was cooked to perfected and to order. way juicy and oh so very tender. $69
* we ended our dinner with the beignets! these are so not the disneyland beignets we know but holy crap are they bomb! that macallan 18 butterscotch sauce, i want to swim in it! that sauce that sauce that sauce!!!! i am not even a btuterscotch person so i am glad i gave it a shot with an open mind because i was blown away! highly recommened!

when they give you the check, they give you a little bag of popcorn on the house. nice little extra touch. 

great place for a date! make sure to call to make reservations.

text:
this was the 4th meal of the recent "vegas food tour" that me and my other <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> to embark on. we loved this place. this was easily the best steakhouse we have ever eaten at! this place gives you a truly <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> as soon as you walk through the door. from the dimmed lighting to the wooden table/chairs to the paper place mat, this was definitely <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>. don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> get me wrong though, this place is still very fancy. not to mention all the freebies they give out! first freebie was the duck fat fries which were... indesc<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> delicious. don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> take all the other review for granted, they are all completely accurate!  second freebie, was the pizza bread. i wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> really a fan of this, it was just way too dense and dry for my liking, and not to mention filling. i wanted to save my stomach for the steak. the third freebie we got was from our waiter steve, at the end of the meal he gave us two packs of caramel/chocolate covered popcorn to enjoy during our mystere show we were going to after dinner, very nice gesture, and we of course tipped him accordingly. =)

with all the freebies we got we decided to go ahead and skip the appetizers and go straight for wine. i ordered a red syrah wine from sonoma (i think) and she ordered a pinot noir (location unknown), i thought both were good, but we ended up switching because she felt that the pinot was tasteless and i thought it was light and amazing.

meat:
we were actually intending to get the japanese <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> according to steve they won<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> be carrying it for another few months due to a mad cow breakout in japan. boo mad cow! regardless, the <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> did not disappoint. i suckered her into getting the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> and i got the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark>. fyi: the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> is 10 times better than the <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>. the steaks were perfectly cooked to our specifications, medium rare. both pieces of meat were delicious but the marbling of the fat in between the crevices of meat in the <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> made it that much more easier to melt in your mouth than the <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>. but please don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> take it the wrong way, the <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> was still one of the best <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> i have ever had. 

sides:
we ended up getting two sides and sharing, which was more than enough. we got the truffled mac and cheese and the jalapeno creamed corn. we already made our decision that we were getting the truffled mac because of all the reviews. one word desc<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> this dish... bold. the flavor was bold and i liked it but i could only have so much. the jalapeno creamed corn on the other hand i could have probably ate the whole bowl. it was a perfect combination of creaminess with a hint of spice to give it a kick. it was very very very good.

dessert:
we got the beignets with creme brulee. the beignets came out warm with dusted powder sugar on top. and the creme brulee was well... creme brulee, nothing too special. it was a delicious end to our meal nonetheless.

this is a definite must eat at spot in vegas. we were torn between cut and stripsteak and i think we made the right decision. next time we are getting the <mark>Japanese A5 Wagyu</mark>!!

pretty cool place. a bunch of stuff was closed at 430 when we ventured here. they have a happy hour menu, consisting of hummus, sliders, salmon poppers, spinach and artichoke brioche and salt and pepper fries. we got 1 of everything.  hummus was fantastic. very very tasty. i didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> eat the sliders, but my friend enjoyed. salmi poppers were......weird. it was raw-i<mark>Scotti Sh Salmon</mark> on top of <mark>Spicy Fried Rice</mark> cake with roe on top. i didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> really care for them too much. they weren<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> bad but wouldn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> order again. the spinach and artichoke was tasty but very very pricey. the salt and pepper fries were way way too salty. all food items about are $7. they give 2 tiny brioche tarts with the spinach dip. 4 would have been better. or at least 3. so, i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> definitely go back and get 2 hummus'. it was definitely my favorite. they have $6 margaritas and monitors. also, some beer and wine is on the happy hour menu. our bartender chris was great. friendly, quick to get our drinks, made them awesome and everything people ordered, he knew. true professional. really enjoyed myself and will most likely return!!!!!

we all tried something different, <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark> vs. <mark><mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> . Australian Wagyu</mark>, <mark>8 Oz <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>, <mark>Scotti Sh Salmon</mark>, <mark>Diver Scallops</mark>, potato puree trio, <mark>Creamed Spinach</mark>. we were all so impressed and pleased with each new thing put before us.

it was a unbelievable meal spent with the greatest company all to celebrate the best man! awesome place to celebrate!

my buddy and i were hungry the other night... we wanted a sit down place to kill some time before hitting the clubs, but we didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> want to spend too much.  i also wanted to eat something healthy.  strip steak didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> originally meet our requirements, but with a coupon from restaurant.com, it did.

we definitely felt like fools not ordering steak here, but oh well, that<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> what we were in the mood for.  i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> already promising myself that i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> going to go back for a steak.

it was good.. but not great.

1. 3 small selections of pommes frites: paprika, truffle, and duck fat each accompanied with their own dipping sauce.

2. garlic / cheese / rosemary flatbread.

as expected the price was high. but for what i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> ordered: a 12oz skirt steak, medium-rare. i expected to have better presentation. not just a slab of beef on a white plate with a <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> baby carrot and small roasted onion as the side. i guess i was expecting a little more show for the price i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> paying.

my steak was cooked perfectly and it was juicy (well it better be for the price i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> paying). but it was nothing special. i don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> know - it<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> hard to explain.. i mean i enjoyed my steak, but it was not memorable.

i ordered a side of truffle mac & cheese. i enjoyed it a lot. it definitely has the truffle and cheese - i dont mind eating the whole thing by myself.

my friend ordered a seared <mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> steak.. which was not good at all. the tuna did not have any fresh tuna taste (not saying it was not fresh.. but a good tuna has a fresh taste).. this one here was kinda bland. like a fake watered down tuna taste (dunno if that even make sense, but that<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> how i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> desc<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> it). i know i know, why would u even order fish at a steakhouse, right? but hey, i still think that if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> going to charge people that price, at least make it look good, even if it doesn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> taste good. 

the presentation for each dish was kinda boring.

i liked that they gave us complimentary bread and fries.  i liked that they kept filing my glass with water.  and i like that my food came out quickly.  i had my <mark>Ahi Tuna</mark>, which came out as a filet. nice and plump.  however, everything here was just decent for me.  nothing spectacular.

we had a great meal here but it definitely wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> the 5-star experience i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> come to expect of michael mina establishments.

maybe it was because we waited so long with a reservation and after coming back within 20 minutes, as they suggested, we waited about 10 more. or the fact that we were seated right next to the entrance which didn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> make for a romantic setting (more like mall dining despite the glass barrier). or that we told a number of people it was our anniversary and no one acknowledged it despite all the other restaurants we visited during the anniversary trip doing so). not sure...but our server was friendly, the recommended wine was tasty and the food was good so 4 stars you get.

was shockingly not a fan of the duck <mark>Crab Spring Rolls</mark> which were too gamey

all in all if you<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> in vegas and want mm, i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> suggest nob hill tavern instead.

we decided to go here for my husband<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> birthday (halloween night). also, a few friends highly recommended this place. so we decided to give it a try. we reserved for two. we did not have to wait at all. they seated us at a small cozy table. 

we ordered the <mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> and <mark><mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> & Hamachi Poppers</mark> for the appetizer. the husband loved it, but i thought it was okay. 

the husband ordered the kobe steak with <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> with a side of scalloped potatoes. the side was fantastic, the <mark>Grilled Foie Gras</mark> gave the steak lots of flavor, but not amazing.

overall, the sides were more amazing than the entrees. the steaks were good, but not mind blowing. at the end of the night, we were disappointed. most likely we will not be coming back anytime soon or in the future.

<mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> and <mark><mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> & Hamachi Poppers</mark> - loved these.  just little circles of crispy rice with a little bit of fish on top with some vinegar/soy sauce concoction 

i hope i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> att<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> the reviews to the right meats, but was rather drunk by this point, so here goes:

<mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> - amazing.  tender, flavorful, and not gussied up by a lot of seasoning.

all in all, it came out to about $150 per person (including tip) with a bunch of wine. so yes, it is pretty expensive, but it definitely is some very good food.

mashed potato trio: big portions!!! wasabi: not too spicy. lobster: delicate and sweet. sour cream and chive: like a pureed mashed potato

duck fat fries: not bad. all three were different enough, and all three were good. i liked the two white dipping sauces that came with them, too.

nice and thoughtful (and free!) congratulations ice cream for the bride to be in our group, and a couple portions of caramel corn to top it off! this was a seriously great experience.

there were 11 of us, and the waiter apologized twice for the long wait, but there really wasn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> a long wait for our food at all. nothing i would have ever complained about. i thought it was odd he was apologizing because i just thought it was a normal wait. they need to turn down the ac though! it was super cold =(

wanting to surprise my fianc\u00e9 with a trip to vegas, i planned everything in advance including dinner reservations. we ended up dining at stripsteak and bouchon for our main dinners, and stripsteak took a notable second place for me out of those two experiences. the food is delicious and the service is great -- there<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> not a question there. i had the tuna and it was cooked to perfection. my fianc\u00e9 had the bone-<mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark> and seemed to be in heaven. we split the bleu cheese scalloped potatoes as a side and started with the <mark><mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> & Hamachi Poppers</mark>, both of which were exceptional. aside from that, we each had a couple of cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> and noshed on their complimentary trio of fries (the truffle fries and aioli -- nom!). still, we somehow managed to tally up quite the bill, which is where my uncer<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> lies. around $230 for the two of us. again, no wine. just a couple of cock<mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> each (sub-$15). we did have a restaurant.com gift certificate which helped, but we were still both a little surprised by the cost of the meal. it was good, but not so memorable where it was worth that investment (at least not in my book).

all in all, i thought it was a very good meal. not exceptional, and -- for me -- not worth the cost when there are so many other exceptional restaurants offering something bit more unique and equally delicious for the same price point. still, i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> happy that i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> checked a michael mina restaurant off the list. i just think i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> have been happier giving that money to bobby flay at mesa grill. :)

yum.

comlimentary trio of fries: truffle, garlic herb and old bay, with matching sauces. tried to stop eating them but could not.

starter salad: wedge with blue cheese. i<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> had this before. why was this one so good?

<mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> tartare starter on crispy rice: adorable presentation, sizable portion and extremely flavorful.

kansas city strip steak and side of jalape\u00f1o creamed corn: steak cooked perfectly. corn slightly underdone gave amazing texture with creamy sauce and background of heat. yum.

service was impeccable yet friendly. sommelier was the most approachable of any i have encountered, yet adequately knowledgeable. atmosphere was lively and pleasant. modern, clean design. 

topper: complimentary dessert to take home. popcorn drizzled with chocolate and other yummy flavors. hints of coffee. addictive.

this was my first michael mina experience and it was a great one. looking forward to trying more.

my wife and i ate here before seeing the michael jackson one show. we wanted a nice steak dinner that was located in mandalay bay so we wouldn<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> have to worry about rushing to the show. all and all it was an ok dinner.  the service was ok, a bit slow and it seemed like we had to find our server every time we wanted a drink. the complimentary trio fries were delicious, like many have said on here. i ordered the <mark>18 Oz Bone in <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark></mark>, cooked medium and it was good.  my wife ordered the halibut and she said it was ok.  we shared the mac and cheese, which we enjoyed very much.  the <mark>Baked Potato</mark> was pretty darn tasty.   the <mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> and <mark><mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> & Hamachi Poppers</mark> appetizer were yummy. my wife and i both agree that we enjoyed the sides and appetizer more then the main entrees.  for drinks, we were also given a digital drink menu via ipad, which i thought was a great idea since drink menu<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> change so frequently. i ordered a corona and my wife ordered the cucumber martini, which she absolutely loved.  i would rate this place at about 3.5 stars, but round up to 4 stars. for a $250 meal, we expected better service and food. i probably would not dine there again, since there are so many other places to eat that offer superior service and food.

good ambiance but like most restaurants in las vegas, overpriced.  and underwhelming. don<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> mind spending $$$ on good food but this left something to be desired. trying to minimize my red meat intake, i got the seared <mark>Ahi Tuna</mark> and market fresh salad. salad was ok but doused in dressing which overwhelmed the plate. greens were fresh. tuna was good but for $41 i was expecting a little more... 

my friend got the wagyu-style beef (8 oz). he was disappointed he spent $81 on an "ok" piece of beef. 

best thing was the complimentary duck fat fries in 3 sauces.

before i explain why i am rating this restaurant a two star, i want to express that my food and and beverages were exceptional.  the beverages were superbly prepared and decorated and the appetizers, side items, main courses and desserts were all eclectic, astonishing and delicious.  with that said, the problems with my experience started from the moment i sat down.  as i scanned thru the food menu, drinks menu and prices, our waiter sidled up and announced the specials.  he was not very personable and seemed unconcerned that we had chosen this restaurant to dine in for the evening. understanding that some people can lack in some areas but make it up in others, i left my thoughts aside and decided to enjoy my dining experience.  the second setback arrived when i placed my wine order.  the waiter had no idea which wine i selected, even though i also pointed to it in the wine menu.  eventually he returned with multiple bottles for me to choose from.  this took a lot longer than it should have for me to order a bottle of wine and was very unprofessional, especially considering how high the prices are.  the waiter then left the table and did not open the bottle in front of us.  i ordered a $90 <mark>Half Lobster Tai L</mark> of wine and i could see the waiter 20 feet away from us, with his back to our table, haggling with this bottle of wine.  when he finally returned to the table, i was over it.  the support staff were all amazing, helpful and smiling, however, our waiter never cracked a smile.  he seemed unskilled and miserable.  when we finished our meal we made him aware that we would have dessert but needed some time to relax.  after dessert he eagerly brought us our bill.  i have been made aware of a couple of service features of strip steak since this experience which have maddened me further.  after a meal, there is a complimentary bag of chocolate kettle corn presented to the guests.  we were not made aware of this kind gesture because our waiter was in a hurry to have us leave the restaurant.  also, i am a local now, which i revealed to our waiter, and i am told that strip steak carries a locals menu, although he was not concerned enough to present one to us.  our bill was over $500 for three people and even though gratuity was added, it was not deserved.  i will always tip wait staff in any situation, but when that situation is a negative one i tend to never return to the restaurant again.  if you are like me when it comes to good professional service, i would suggest you skip this restaurant as well.  on a side note, a female member of our party visited the restroom facilities, which are unisex, and she walked in on a gentleman who had not locked the door.  she was very embarrassed by this and mentioned it to our waiter.  he seemed offended that we had an issue with the restroom policy of the restaurant and acted as if it were our problem.  our only suggestion was that they have a dedicated woman<mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> restroom and that others could remain unisex.

first trip to stripsteak.  

we had - 
1.  complimentary duck fat fries

5.  truffle mac <mark>8 Oz Amer Ican Wagyu Rib ' Eye '</mark> cheese ($12) - absolutely heavenly, so decadent

total bill was $113 before tax and tip for 2 of us.
